newsitem.title: GREECE: GREECE TO INAUGURATE NATURAL GAS TRANSPORT SYSTEM.
newsitem.headline: GREECE TO INAUGURATE NATURAL GAS TRANSPORT SYSTEM.

text.p: Greece's Prime Minster Costas Simitis will inaugurate the country's Natural Gas Transportation System on January 14, the Public Gas Corporation (DEPA) said in a statement.
The inauguration will be attended by Russia's Energy Minister P. Rodionov and Rao Gazprom president Rem Viachirev.
The project is budgeted at 700 billion drachmas.

"The natural gas project is handled by the Public Gas Corporation of Greece (DEPA). The project involves natural gas transportation, via pipeline, from Russia and liquid gas transfer in tankers, from Algeria," a geotechnical consultant to the project told Reuters.
"Construction has gone ahead, especially in the areas of Attica, eastern Macedonia, central and northern Greece," he added.
The complete natural gas project will include a central pipeline, distribution networks and maintenance centers.
The central pipeline which will transfer high-pressure natural gas from the Greek-Bulgarian border to Attica will have a length of 511 kilometers.
Distribution of both high and low pressure natural gas has also been accounted for.
High-pressure gas will be transported to eastern Macedonia, Thrace, the Attica region and to the cities of Volos and Thessaloniki.
Low-pressure gas distribution networks will cover a length 6,500 kilometers between the cities of Athens, Piraeus, Thessaloniki, Larisa and Volos.
Another three control and maintenance units are planned for Attica, Larisa and Thessaloniki.

The central gas pipeline has been operating since September 17 1996. On November 15, Hellenic Sugar Industry's Larisa plant became connected with the pipeline making it the first industrial unit in Greece to use natural gas as fuel, DEPA said. --Margarita Sotiropoulou, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
